content:
It's possible to use abstract category theory as practiced in a [[proarrow equipment]] to set up a correspondence between category theory and topos theory, so I started to do this. So far I have:

Category Theory Topos Theory
category C,DC,DC,D topos E,F \mathscr{E}, \mathscr{F} E,F
functor F,G:C→DF,G : C \rarr DF,G:C→D geometric morphism f,g:E→F f,g : \mathscr{E} \rarr \mathscr{F} f,g:E→F
profunctor P,Q:C⇸DP,Q : C ⇸ D P,Q:C⇸D lex functor H,K:F→E H,K : \mathscr{F} \rarr \mathscr{E} H,K:F→E (note direction)
natural transformation α:P⇒Q\alpha : P \rArr Qα:P⇒Q natural transformation α:K⇒H \alpha : K \rArr H α:K⇒H (note direction)
D(1,F)D(1,F)D(1,F) f∗f^{*}f∗
D(F,1)D(F,1)D(F,1) f∗f_{*}f∗​
P(F,G)P(F,G)P(F,G) g∗∘H∘f∗g^{*} \circ H \circ f_{*}g∗∘H∘f∗​
collage of PPP Artin gluing of HHH
cocone under CCC Freyd cover of E\mathscr{E}E
cone over CCC Artin gluing of LConstLConstLConst (sometimes called Δ\DeltaΔ)
111 SetSetSet
222 (walking arrow) Sierpinski topos = Set2Set^{2}Set2
!!! Γ\GammaΓ (global sections functor)
000 Initial topos
Cauchy completeness (trivial)
presheaf lex functor C→SetC \rarr SetC→Set
representable presheaf lex left adjoint functor C→SetC \rarr SetC→Set
object A,B:CA,B : CA,B:C point p,qp,qp,q of E\mathscr{E}E
arrow f:A→Bf : A \rarr Bf:A→B ??? (geometric morphism from the Sierpinski topos mapping the open point to ppp and the closed point to qqq)
walking arrow classifies analyses of CCC as collage Sierpinski topos classifies analyses of E\mathscr{E}E as Artin gluing
fully faithful functor geometric embedding
PPP-weighted limit of FFF ??? (a geometric morphism whose inverse image is LiftHf∗\mathrm{Lift}_{H} f^{*}LiftH​f∗)
conical limit of FFF ??? (a geometric morphism whose inverse image is LiftLConstf∗\mathrm{Lift}_{LConst} f^{*}LiftLConst​f∗
terminal object focal point (this should agree with the above but I haven't checked)
pointwise Rangf\mathrm{Ran}_{g} fRang​f ??? (a geometric morphism whose inverse image is LiftH∗f∗\mathrm{Lift}_{H_{*}} f^{*}LiftH∗​​f∗)

Can anyone identify any of the "???" or anything left out?
Nice! Are you getting this from Proarrows II?

Christian Williams said:

Nice! Are you getting this from Proarrows II?

I basically worked it out myself based on the definitions in the nLab ... on reading Proarrows II it mentions the interesting fact that lex functors are actually the codiscrete cofibrations in TOP ... which is a nice confirmation that they are actually the right thing to use as the analogue to profunctors, but that seems highly overdetermined at this point.

No doubt I'm getting some of that indirectly through the nLab too ...

Adding:

Category theory Topos theory
sieve in CCC open subtopos of E\mathscr{E}E
cosieve in CCC closed subtopos of E\mathscr{E}E
BTW although little of this is in Proarrows II in particular I'd be surprised if much of it was truly original so references are welcome as well ...
How do you prove that the analogue of fully faithful functors are the embeddings? They're certainly internally fully faithful, but do you know how to prove the converse?

I'm using the definition of fully faithful from https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/2-category+equipped+with+proarrows#fully_faithful_arrows and computing it out with the above dictionary, get that the definition is that f∗∘f∗f^{*} \circ f_{*}f∗∘f∗​ is canonically isomorphic to ididid via the counit of the adjunction f∗⊣f∗f^{*} \dashv f_{*}f∗⊣f∗​ which is the second equivalent condition at https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/geometric+embedding#definition ...
Right -- in particular, a "fully faithful arrow" in a proarrow equipment is a stronger condition than being representably fully faithful in its 2-category of arrows.

I think the ??? corresponding to f:A→Bf:A\to Bf:A→B should be just "a morphism of points". The points of any topos form a category. (In the case of a classifying topos of some theory, the morphisms are the morphisms of models of that theory.)
Although, since the proarrow equipment of topoi is not "well-pointed" the way Cat/Prof is, the points and their morphisms (with terminal domain) are generally less important.
Indeed; I similarly expect that for limits and colimits the ones that are properly proarrow-weighted rather than merely (co)presheaf-weighted are going to be important.
I look forward to hearing what those turn out to be!
It might be interesting already to ask what they are in the simpler proarrow equipment of locales.
You might also be interested in this paper by Susan Niefield.

James Deikun said:

Christian Williams said:

Nice! Are you getting this from Proarrows II?

I basically worked it out myself based on the definitions in the nLab ... on reading Proarrows II it mentions the interesting fact that lex functors are actually the codiscrete cofibrations in TOP ... which is a nice confirmation that they are actually the right thing to use as the analogue to profunctors, but that seems highly overdetermined at this point.

No doubt I'm getting some of that indirectly through the nLab too ...

Be patient with me, because this is my first time looking into proarrow equipments, but how is this overdetermined? Wood uses the (bi)functor Top→TopLexco\mathrm{Top} \to \mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{co}}Top→TopLexco which forgets the inverse image functor as his proarrow equipment. Something which would seem much more natural to me would be the (bi)functor Top→TopLexop\mathrm{Top} \to \mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{op}}Top→TopLexop which forgets the direct image functor. Why is the former the one you choose? Is it actually the one you use?
More generally, I'm sure there are other possible proarrow equipments for toposes. You can't present a table like the one above without saying which one you're using!

More generally, I'm sure there are other possible proarrow equipments for toposes.

In many cases, the proarrow equipment structure is essentially unique, and this is true in this example. See Rosebrugh–Wood's Proarrows and cofibrations.
Though Morgan's original point is right up to taking opposite categories! See Rosebrugh–Wood's Cofibrations in the bicategory of topoi. :P

Nathanael Arkor said:

More generally, I'm sure there are other possible proarrow equipments for toposes.

In many cases, the proarrow equipment structure is essentially unique, and this is true in this example. See Rosebrugh–Wood's Proarrows and cofibrations.

The conditions on the proarrow equipment (−)∗:K→M(-)_*: K \to M(−)∗​:K→M that they use in this paper which result in essential uniqueness are...

MMM has all finite collages. All collage injections i:A→Ci: A \to Ci:A→C are in KKK. An arrow C→XC \to XC→X is in KKK if and only if all A→C→XA \to C \to XA→C→X are in KKK. Applying (−)∗(-)^*(−)∗ to a collage diagram yields an opcollage diagram.

That's a lot of non-trivial conditions, certainly enough to support my argument that you should specify which equipment you're using.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

Be patient with me, because this is my first time looking into proarrow equipments, but how is this overdetermined? Wood uses the (bi)functor Top→TopLexco\mathrm{Top} \to \mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{co}}Top→TopLexco which forgets the inverse image functor as his proarrow equipment. Something which would seem much more natural to me would be the (bi)functor Top→TopLexop\mathrm{Top} \to \mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{op}}Top→TopLexop which forgets the direct image functor. Why is the former the one you choose? Is it actually the one you use?

I'm actually using the functor Topco→TopLexcoop\mathrm{Top}^{\mathrm{co}} \to \mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{coop}}Topco→TopLexcoop which forgets direct image, as it seems to be the most natural in this case, hence all the (note direction) above ... the inverse image functor is a left adjoint. I want it to be the 'forward' direction because it is more important in applications, and I want it to remain the left adjoint because that's what's proper for 'forward' in equipments. However in TopLexop\mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{op}}TopLexop it is a right adjoint, so the extra co^{co}co is needed.

Now I guess I need to look into Proarrows and cofibrations to see what I might be missing by not using their orientation ...

James Deikun said:

However in TopLexop\mathrm{TopLex}^{\mathrm{op}}TopLexop it is a right adjoint, so the extra co^{co}co is needed.

Ah I see, variance being tricky as usual :joy: I'm glad I took the time to ask!

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

That's a lot of non-trivial conditions, certainly enough to support my argument that you should specify which equipment you're using.

It looks like a lot of conditions when expressed in terms of a bo-lff functor (−)∗:K→M(-)_* : K\to M(−)∗​:K→M, but from an enriched perspective it's really just a cocompleteness condition.

So @Mike Shulman is it the case that the difference between the proarrow equipments we've been discussing is that they satisfy a completeness and cocompleteness condition respectively? Are they "the same" equipment in some sense, up to suitably dualizing the bicategories involved? This is still unclear to me.

I don't know for certain, but I think the notion of proarrow equipment is not self-dual and the one is a proarrow equipment for the category and the other is for its opposite category. I don't think they are 'equivalent' equipments.

Let's see. Both kinds of 2-categorical duality reverse the handedness of internal adjoints, i.e. a left adjoint in CCC is a right adjoint in CopC^{op}Cop and CcoC^{co}Cco, and a left adjoint in CcoopC^{coop}Ccoop. Thus, if K→MK\to MK→M is a proarrow equipment, then Kop→MopK^{op} \to M^{op}Kop→Mop and Kco→McoK^{co} \to M^{co}Kco→Mco are not, but Kcoop→McoopK^{coop} \to M^{coop}Kcoop→Mcoop is.

On the other hand, if (−)∗:K→M(-)_* : K\to M(−)∗​:K→M is an equipment, i.e. a bo+lff functor such that each f∗f_*f∗​ has a right adjoint f∗f^*f∗, then since adjoints point in the opposite direction and passage to adjoints reverses 2-cells, we also have a functor (−)∗:K→Mcoop(-)^* : K\to M^{coop}(−)∗:K→Mcoop. By the above, each f∗f^*f∗ is still a right adjoint in McoopM^{coop}Mcoop, so this is not an equipment. But applying one more duality of either sort fixes that, so (−)∗:Kop→Mco(-)^* : K^{op} \to M^{co}(−)∗:Kop→Mco and (−)∗:Kco→Mop(-)^* : K^{co} \to M^{op}(−)∗:Kco→Mop are both equipments (and, of course, one is the coop of the other).

In other words, the Klein 4-group acts on equipments, but the action isn't simply lifted from the action on 2-categories: it acts differently on KKK and MMM.

Now there is a "tautological" equipment Adj→Cat\rm Adj \to CatAdj→Cat, where Adj\rm AdjAdj is the 2-category of categories and adjunctions pointing in the direction of their left adjoints. Thus, we also have equipments Adjcoop→Catcoop\rm Adj^{coop} \to Cat^{coop}Adjcoop→Catcoop, Adjop→Catco\rm Adj^{op} \to Cat^{co}Adjop→Catco, and Adjco→Catop\rm Adj^{co} \to Cat^{op}Adjco→Catop, where the first two send an adjunction to its left adjoint, and the second two send an adjunction to its right adjoint.

It sounds like in this conversation we're defining Top\rm TopTop as a subcategory of AdjopAdj^{op}Adjop, with geometric morphisms pointing in the direction of their right adjoint, but with 2-cells defined as going between their left adjoints. Thus, we have equipments Topop→TopLex\rm Top^{op} \to TopLexTopop→TopLex, Topco→TopLexcoop\rm Top^{co} \to TopLex^{coop}Topco→TopLexcoop, Top→TopLexco\rm Top \to TopLex^{co}Top→TopLexco, and Topcoop→Catop\rm Top^{coop} \to Cat^{op}Topcoop→Catop. Since they constitute an orbit of the Klein-4 action, they all carry the same information.

Hmm. This is interesting. How this this square with Roseburgh and Wood's comment on the second page of "Cofibrations in the bicategory of topoi" that "the proarrow equipment TOP→LEXco\mathrm{TOP} \to \mathrm{LEX}^\mathrm{co}TOP→LEXco enjoys more of the properties of CAT→Prof\mathrm{CAT} \to \mathrm{Prof}CAT→Prof than does TOPop→LEX\mathrm{TOP}^\mathrm{op} \to \mathrm{LEX}TOPop→LEX"? Does this mean they were mistaken here or am I misunderstanding something?
"Carrying the same information" doesn't mean that they're the same or have the same properties. Set\rm SetSet and Setop\rm Set^{op}Setop carry the same information, but one is a topos and one isn't.
I see. Fair enough.
